Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\) representing a wave at frequency \\( \omega \\), and the Laplace Transform \\( \mathcal{L} \\) which transforms \\( z(t) \\) into the s-domain as \\( Z(s) = \\frac{1}{s - i \omega} \\). Analyze the influence of multiplying \\( z(t) \\) by a decay function \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\), where \\( \alpha \\) is a positive constant, before applying the Laplace Transform.

If we apply the decay function \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) to \\( z(t) \\) and then perform the Laplace Transform without any other manipulation, will the transformed function \\( Z(s) \\) become \\( \\frac{1}{s + \alpha - i \omega} \\)?
Explanation: When applying the decay function \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) directly to \\( z(t) \\), it modifies the input of the Laplace Transform. The resulting transformed function now includes the decay rate \\( \alpha \\) in its s-domain representation, correctly adjusting the original pole from \\( s = i \omega \\) to \\( s = \alpha + i \omega \\), thus yielding \\( Z(s) = \\frac{1}{s + \alpha - i \omega} \\).
